sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
This record can be found on pp. 689 of REED: Inns of Court, Vol. 2
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

mods:mods.mods:abstract: John Chamberlain (1553-1628) was a professional letter-writer employed by contemporaries who preserved his letters in considerable numbers. Chief among his employers was Sir Dudley Carlteton (1574-1632), Viscount Dorchester, a career diplomat who served in Venice from 1610 to 1615. (Carleton was admitted to Gray's Inn in 1605). Carleton's sister Alice was a favourite of Chamberlain. This letter, dated 18 February 1612/13, describes the performance events staged for the wedding of Princess Elizabeth to Frederick, Elector Palatine.
mods:mods.mods:accessCondition: Use of this public-domain resource is governed by the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 4.0 International License.

mods:recordInfo.mods:recordOrigin: This MODS record was created using the Islandora XML Forms collection of Drupal modules.

div.head: Letter of John Chamberlain to Sir Ralph Winwood

div.ab: My very goode Lord: since my last of the 10th of this present here hath ben litle to aduertise, but the consummation of the Lady Elizabeths marriage with the Count Palatin, together with the triumphes and shewes bothbefore and after....

div.head: ff 1v-2
div.ab: ...now for the fireworks and fight vpon the water, (the one performed the thursday nightthursday night: , the other on saterdaysaterday: in the afternoone before the marriage) there was nothing in either awnswerable to the great reputation concerned, or the cost bestowed, which amounted to more then 9000 li. so that according to the prouerb Parturiunt montes etceteracp Horace,Ars Poetica 139: marry they pretend the best was kept back for another day, but the king and indeed all the companie were so sufficiently vnsatisfied with this, that they cared not, nor desired to see any more, the rather for that there was much hurt don, and diuers maymed. the Lords maske likewise on the mariage night, though yt were very rich and sumptuous, yet it was long and tedious, and with many deuises more lyke a play then a maske. but the middle Templers and Lincolns ynne gaue great contentment on monday night monday night: , as well with theyre gracefull comming on horsebacke, as in all the rest of theyre apt inuention, apparell, fashion, and specially theyre excellent dauncing, wherewith the king was so much delighted that he gaue them many thancks, and much commendation as well to theyre faces as behind theyre backs. but the next dayth enext day: our Grayes ynne men and the inner Temple had not the same fortune, though they deserued no lesse: for striuing to varie from theyre competitors, (and theyre deuise being the marieng of the Thames to the Rhine,) they made choise to go by water from winchester house in Southwarke, with theyre boats and barges excedingly trimmed, and furnished with store of lights that made a glorious shew, and three peale of ordinance (at theyre taking water, at theyre passing by the Temple, and at theyre landing,) which passage by water cost them better then 300 li. but when they were landed at the court, (by what mischaunce I know not) they were faine to return as they went without dooing any thing, the reason wherof some say was because the hall was so full that yt could not be avoyded nor roome made for them, and most of the principall Ladies (that were in the galleries to see theyre landing) excluded: but the most probable is that the King was so satiated, and overwearied with watching the two nights before, that he could hold out no longer, and so was driuen to put yt of till saterday20 February 1612/13, whyt was very well performed in the new banket house,which for a kind of amends was graunted to t though with much repining and contradiction of theyre emulators. the next day21 February 1612/13 the King made them all a solemne supper in the new mariage roome, and vsed them so well and graciously that he sent both parties away well pleased....
